text: here at the 2014 north american
international auto show the most
significant debutant is not a car but a
truck it's this truck a Ford f-150 and
the thing that makes it so special it's
made mostly of aluminum with the f-150
there's a lot at stake at Ford because
it's not only their number one selling
vehicle it's the number one selling
vehicle in the country and it's been
that way for almost four decades when
you talk to a full-size pickup truck
market you're talking to a very
conservative market they like things the
way they've always had them there's a
lot of people in the construction
business a lot of tradesmen it's a very
conservative grew and it's mostly guys
and this is very different in terms of
body construction I think there will be
some questions in some people's minds
about durability about how rugged this
vehicle is we dropped this 78 ford
pickup straight down in a freefall
traditionally fjords marketing pitch for
their trucks has been that they'd build
trucks ford tough and that means steel
now it means aluminum your priority a
number one is to make sure that you
deliver built ford tough so when we talk
about the future of tough we want to
really communicate clearly that this
what looks to be radical departure to
high-strength aluminum alloy is one
that's going to deliver not a truck that
is just equal to today's truck but a
truck that's superior in terms of
toughness dent and ding resistance in
the bed in the on offenders with the
door panels so that's really the purpose
of it Ford has been a maverick when it
comes to marketing their trucks for a
long time now nobody thought they could
sell v6 turbocharged engines instead of
v8 but Ford has proved them wrong that
time and they hope with aluminum they
can prove them wrong again as we've
taken 700 pounds of weight out of the
truck that were then able to reinvest in
key attributes for the truck customer
things like more towing more hauling
better fuel economy
all things that help make the truck a
better tool it's interesting that they
launched at this time because their key
competitors are already set literally
set in steals for the next several years
so they are taking a forward-looking
stance Ford of course will have to prove
that this material is durable but they
believe they can do it because they
think that they have a jumpstart in
aluminium technology because they've
been working on this for a number of
years before they decided to take the
big leap here for the New York Times
this is Jerry Garrett
